raw_text:
Gatlin and Hayes win Owen awards
 
 American Olympic stars Justin Gatlin and Joanna Hayes have been named the winners of the 2004 Jesse Owens Awards, USA Track & Field's (USATF) top honour.
 
 Gatlin, 22, won the closest 100m final in Games history with a career-best time of 9.85 seconds in Athens. He also won bronze in the 200m and silver in the 4x100m relay, becoming the only male athlete to win three athletics medals this summer. Hayes, 27, set an Olympic record of 12.37 in winning the 100m hurdles. Established in 1981, the Jesse Owens Awards - named in honour of the late Olympic great who won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Games - are presented annually to the outstanding US male and female track and field performers.
 
 The 2004 awards will be presented on 3 December in conjunction with the USATF annual meeting in Portland. "It is such a great honour to win the Jesse Owens Award," said Gatlin. "It is one of the biggest honours in track and field and it is a great end to a great year. " Hayes said: "Knowing some of the great people who have won this award before me and knowing what it represents, I feel a sense accomplishment and pride which lets me know that everything that I have worked for is and always will be worth it."
llama3.2:1b:
Justin Gatlin and Joanna Hayes were awarded the 2004 Jesse Owens Awards. 

Gatlin won the 100m and 4x100m relay in Athens, and set a new Olympic record in the 100m hurdles. 
Hayes broke an Olympic record with her winning time of 12.37 seconds in the 100m hurdles.

The awards were presented on December 3, 2004, at USATF's annual meeting.
llama3.2:3b: Justin Gatlin and Joanna Hayes win 2004 Jesse Owens Awards; Gatlin set career-best time in Athens; Hayes won Olympic record in 100m hurdles.

qwen2.5:3b: American Olympic stars Justin Gatlin and Joanna Hayes were named winners of the 2004 Jesse Owens Awards by USA Track & Field (USATF). Gatlin, aged 22, set a record in the 100m with a time of 9.85 seconds, winning bronze in the 200m and silver in the 4x100m relay. Hayes, aged 27, broke an Olympic record in the 100m hurdles. The Jesse Owens Awards are given annually to top US track and field performers, honoring athletes like Owens who won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Games. Gatlin and Hayes will be presented with their awards on December 3rd during a meeting of USATF in Portland.
opencoder:1.5b:
The American Olympic stars Justin Gatlin and Joanna Hayes have been named the winners of the 2004 Jesse Owens Awards. They achieved a prestigious position at the Games history has gained them three gold medals. Gatlin, a22 year old male, won the closest 100m final time with an impressive career record of 9.85 seconds in Athens. He also won two gold medals in the 200m and silver medal in the 4x100m relay, marking him as one of the only men to win three distinct sports records this summer. Hayes, a27 year old female, set a thrilling record at the 100m hurdles, winning it first time ever in a single season.
The annual USATF presentation on 3 December, with its annual meeting in Portland, has been dedicated to celebrating the outstanding track and field performers of this century. Gatlin said, "I am sure that many of you have known some of the great athletes who have won this award before me. The Olympic spirit and discipline continue to inspire and instill in us a sense of achievement and pride."
